SMufoLib
  • Objects
  • Edit on GitHub

Objects

Base Objects

SMufoLib’s most low-level classes are simply implementations of the fontParts.base equivalents. As such, SMufoLib provides easy access to an entire common font development API in addition to functionality specific to SMuFL. Please see the FontParts documentation for further reference.

class Font(pathOrObject=None, showInterface=True)[source]

Environment implementation of fontParts.base.BaseFont.

To import the Font object and instantiate a font:

>>> from smufolib import Font
>>> font = Font('path/to/my/font.ufo')
layerClass

alias of Layer

property smufl: Smufl

Font instance of Smufl.

class Glyph(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Environment implementation of fontParts.base.BaseGlyph.

Glyphs are usually accessed through a Font objects inherent glyph dictionary. To instantiate the SMuFL glyph named uniE030 (single barline):

>>> glyph = font['uniE030']
property smufl: Smufl

Glyph instance of Smufl.

class Layer(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Environment implementation of fontParts.base.BaseLayer.

glyphClass

alias of Glyph

Core Objects

The following classes represent SMufoLib’s metadata collection classes.

Caution

These classes use fontParts.base.BaseLib to store property settings. Editing these keys directly may cause problems.

class Smufl(font=None, glyph=None)[source]

Provides SMuFL-related metadata and functionality.

Class may be called from either Font or Glyph. Font-specific attributes with unique names may be accessed from both, due to the consistent access to parent classes in FontParts.

Note

Attributes with the purpose of identifying ligatures (isLigature), stylistic alternates (isSalt) and stylistic sets (isSet) depend on strict adherence to the descriptive naming schemes stipulated in the Adobe Glyph List Specification and followed by the SMuFL standard (see Section 6 for more information).

Tip

To avoid having to set all the glyph identification attributes manually, it is advisable to run the script importID prior to using this class with an excisting font for the first time.

Parameters:

  • font (Font | None) – Parent Font object.

  • glyph (Glyph | None) – Parent Glyph object.

While this object is normally created as part of a Font, an orphan Smufl object can be created like this:

>>> smufl = Smufl()
findGlyph(name)[source]

Finds Glyph object from name.

Parameters:

name (str) – SMuFL-specific canonical glyph name.

Return type:

Glyph | None

Example:

>>> font.smufl.findGlyph('barlineSingle')
<Glyph 'uniE030' ('public.default') at 4393557200>
round()[source]

Rounds font units to integers.

Method applies to the following attributes:

  • engravingDefaults

  • anchors

  • advanceWidth

If spaces is True, values are left unchanged.

Examples:

>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
230.5
>>> glyph.smufl.round()
>>> glyph.smufl.wiadvanceWidthdth
230.5

>>> glyph.smufl.spaces = True
>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
0.922
>>> glyph.smufl.round()
>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
0.922
Return type:

None

toSpaces(value)[source]

Converts font units to staff spaces based on font UPM size.

The inverse of toUnits().

Parameters:

value (int | float) – Value to convert.

Return type:

float | None

Example:

>>> f = Font('path/to/my/font.ufo')
>>> font.info.unitsPerEm
2048
>>> font.smufl.toSpaces(512)
1.0
toUnits(value)[source]

Converts staff spaces to font units based on font UPM size.

The inverse of toSpaces(). Result is always rounded.

Parameters:

value (int | float) – Value to convert.

Return type:

int | None

Example:

>>> f = Font('path/to/my/font.ufo')
>>> font.info.unitsPerEm
2048
>>> font.smufl.toSpaces(2)
1024
property advanceWidth: int | float | None

Glyph advance width.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
671
property alternates: tuple[dict[str, str], ...] | None

Metadata of glyph alternates.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE050'] # gClef
>>> glyph.smufl.alternates
({'codepoint': 'U+F472', 'name': 'gClefSmall'},)
property anchors: dict[str, tuple[int | float, int | float]] | None

SMuFL-specific glyph anchors as Cartesian coordinates.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE0A3'] # noteheadHalf
>>> glyph.smufl.anchors
{'cutOutNW': (0.204, 0.296), 'cutOutSE':
(0.98, -0.3), 'splitStemDownNE': (0.956, -0.3), 'splitStemDownNW':
(0.128, -0.428), 'splitStemUpSE': (1.108, 0.372), 'splitStemUpSW':
(0.328, 0.38), 'stemDownNW': (0.0, -0.168), 'stemUpSE': (1.18, 0.168)}
property bBox: dict[str, tuple[int | float, int | float]] | None

Glyph bounding box as Cartesian coordinates.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.bBox
{'bBoxSW': (0.0, -0.5), 'bBoxNE': (1.18, 0.5)}
property base: Glyph | None

Glyph object of alternate’s base glyph.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE050.ss01']
>>> glyph.smufl.base
<Glyph 'uniE050' ('public.default') at 4373577008>
property classes: tuple[str, ...] | None

SMuFL-specific class memberships.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE354'] # accSagittalSharp7v11kUp
>>> glyph.smufl.classes
['accidentals', 'accidentalsSagittalAthenian', 'combiningStaffPositions']
property codepoint: str | None

Unicode codepoint as formatted string.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE0A3']
>>> glyph.smufl.codepoint
U+E0A3
property componentGlyphs: tuple[str, ...] | None

Ligature components by name.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE09E_uniE083_uniE09F_uniE084']
>>> glyph.smufl.componentGlyphs
('timeSigCombNumerator', 'timeSig3', 'timeSigCombDenominator', 'timeSig4')
property description: str | None

SMuFL-specific glyph description of optional glyphs.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.description
Combining swished stem
property designSize: int | None

Optimum point size in integral decipoints.

Example:

>>> font.smufl.designSize
240
property engravingDefaults: EngravingDefaults

Font’s EngravingDefaults object.

Example:

>>> font.smufl.engravingDefaults
<EngravingDefaults at 4540156752>
property font: Font | None

Parent Font object.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.font
<Font 'MyFont' path='path/to/my/font.ufo' at 4405856720>
property glyph: Glyph | None

Parent Glyph object.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.glyph
<Glyph 'uniE587' ('public.default') at 4536458160>
property isLigature: bool

Returns True if glyph is ligature.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE09E_uniE083_uniE09F_uniE084']
>>> g1.smufl.isLigature
True
>>> glyph = font['uniE083']
>>> glyph.smufl.isLigature
False
property isMember: bool

Returns True if glyph is either recommended or optional.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE050']
>>> glyph.smufl.isMember
True
>>> glyph = font['spaces']
>>> glyph.smufl.isMember
False
property isOptional: bool

Returns True if glyph is optional.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniF660']
>>> g1.smufl.isOptional
True
>>> glyph = font['uniE083']
>>> glyph.smufl.isOptional
False
property isRecommended: bool

Returns True if glyph is recommended.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE083']
>>> g1.smufl.isRecommended
True
>>> glyph = font['uniF660']
>>> glyph.smufl.isRecommended
False
property isSalt: bool

Returns True if glyph is stylistic alternate.

Accepts both '.alt' and '.salt' suffix. See Note about glyph naming.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE042.salt01']
>>> glyph.smufl.isSalt
True
>>> glyph = font['uniE042']
>>> glyph.smufl.isSalt
False
property isSet: bool

Returns True if glyph is stylistic set member.

See Note about glyph naming.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE050.ss01']
>>> glyph.smufl.isSet
True
>>> glyph = font['uniE042.salt01']
>>> glyph.smufl.isSet
False
property layer: Layer | None

Parent Layer object.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.layer
<Layer 'public.default' at 4568631952>
property name: str | None

SMuFL-specific canonical font or glyph name.

Examples:

>>> font.smufl.name
Bravura

>>> glyph = font['uniE212']
>>> glyph.smufl.name
stemSwished
property range: Range

Glyph’s Range object.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE212'] # stemSwished
>>> glyph.smufl.range
<Range 'stems' ('U+E210–U+E21F') at 4348391632>
property sizeRange: tuple[int, int] | None

Optimum size range in integral decipoints.

Example:

>>> font.smufl.designSize
(180, 260)
property spaces: bool

State of measurement.

Example:

>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
230.5
>>> glyph.smufl.spaces = True
>>> glyph.smufl.advanceWidth
0.922
property suffix: str | None

Returns suffix of alternates.

Example:

>>> glyph = font['uniE050.ss01']
>>> glyph.smufl.suffix
ss01
property version: float | None

SMuFL-specific font version number.

Example:

>>> font.smufl.version
2.2
class EngravingDefaults(smufl=None)[source]

SMuFL engraving default settings.

This object contains properties and methods pertained to SMuFL’s engravingDefaults metadata structure, defining recommended defaults for line widths etc., according to the specification.

the EngravingDefaults object is essentially a dict with access to keys through regular class attributes.

Tip

Engraving default values can be calculated from the contours of specific glyphs and set automatically with the calculateEngravingDefaults script.

Parameters:

smufl (Smufl | None) – Parent Smufl object.

While this object is normally created as part of a Font, an orphan EngravingDefaults object may be created like this:

>>> d = EngravingDefaults()
clear()[source]

Clears all engraving default settings.

Example:

>>> d.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}
>>> d.clear()
>>> d.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': None, 'barlineSeparation': None, ...}
Return type:

None

items()[source]

Returns dict of all available settings and their values.

Example:

>>> d = f.smufl.engravingDefaults
>>> d.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}
Return type:

dict[str, int | float | tuple[str, …] | None]

keys()[source]

Returns sorted list of all available settings names.

Example:

>>> d = f.smufl.engravingDefaults
>>> d.keys()
['arrowShaftThickness', 'barlineSeparation', ...]
Return type:

list[str]

round()[source]

Rounds font units to integers.

Method applies to the following attributes:

  • arrowShaftThickness

  • barlineSeparation

  • beamSpacing

  • beamThickness

  • bracketThickness

  • dashedBarlineDashLength

  • dashedBarlineGapLength

  • dashedBarlineThickness

  • hairpinThickness

  • hBarThickness

  • legerLineExtension

  • legerLineThickness

  • lyricLineThickness

  • octaveLineThickness

  • pedalLineThickness

  • repeatBarlineDotSeparation

  • repeatEndingLineThickness

  • slurEndpointThickness

  • slurMidpointThickness

  • staffLineThickness

  • stemThickness

  • subBracketThickness

  • textEnclosureThickness

  • thickBarlineThickness

  • thinBarlineThickness

  • thinThickBarlineSeparation

  • tieEndpointThickness

  • tieMidpointThickness

  • tupletBracketThickness

If spaces is True, values are left unchanged.

Example:

>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
30.5
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.round()
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
31

>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.spaces = True
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
0.12
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.round()
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
0.12
Return type:

None

update(other=None, **kwargs)[source]

Updates settings attributes with other object or values.

Parameters:

  • other (EngravingDefaults | dict[str, int | float | tuple[str, ...] | None] | None) – Other EngravingDefaults or dict of attribute names mapped to values.

  • **kwargs (int | float | tuple[str, ...] | None) – Optional attribute names and values as keyword arguments.

Return type:

None

An object may be updated in a few different ways:

>>> d1 = f.smufl.engravingDefaults
>>> d1.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': None, 'barlineSeparation': None, ...}

Update with dict object.:

>>> d2 = {'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}
>>> d1.update(d2)
>>> d1.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}

Update with other EngravingDefaults object.:

>>> d2 = f2.smufl.engravingDefaults
>>> d2.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}
>>> d1.update(d2)
>>> d1.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}

Update with keyword arguments:

>>> d1.update(arrowShaftThickness=46, barlineSeparation=72)
>>> d1.items()
{'arrowShaftThickness': 46, 'barlineSeparation': 72, ...}
values()[source]

Returns list of all available settings values.

Order corresponds to keys().

Example:

>>> d = f.smufl.engravingDefaults
>>> d.values()
[46, 72, 62, 125, 125, 125, 57, 36, 200, 39, 80, 40, ...]
Return type:

list[str]

property arrowShaftThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the line used for the shaft of an arrow.

property barlineSeparation: int | float | None

Distance between multiple thin barlines.

Distance between beams.

Thickness of a beam.

property bracketThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the vertical line of a grouping bracket.

property dashedBarlineDashLength: int | float | None

Length of the dashes to be used in a dashed barline.

Length of the gap between dashes in a dashed barline.

property dashedBarlineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of a dashed barline.

Parent Font object.

Parent Glyph object.

Parent Layer object.

property legerLineExtension: int | float | None

Amount of leger line extension from notehead.

property legerLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of a leger line.

property lyricLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the lyric extension line.

property octaveLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the dashed line used for an octave line.

property pedalLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the line used for piano pedaling.

property repeatBarlineDotSeparation: int | float | None

Distance between dots and inner line of a repeat barline.

property repeatEndingLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of repeat ending brackets.

property slurEndpointThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the end of a slur.

property slurMidpointThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the mid-point of a slur.

property smufl: Smufl | None

Parent Smufl.

property spaces: bool

State of measurement.

Example:

>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
30.5
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.spaces = True
>>> f.smufl.engravingDefaults.stemThickness
0.12
property staffLineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of each staff line.

Thickness of a stem.

Thickness of the vertical line of a grouping sub-bracket.

property textEnclosureThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of box drawn around text instructions.

property textFontFamily: tuple[str, ...]

tuple of text font pairings.

property thickBarlineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of a thick barline.

property thinBarlineThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of a thin barline.

Thickness of a thin barline.

Thickness of the end of a tie.

property tieMidpointThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of the mid-point of a tie.

property tupletBracketThickness: int | float | None

Thickness of tuplet brackets.

Range metadata module for SMufoLib.

class Range(smufl=None)[source]

SMuFL range-related metadata.

Information about how a Glyph relates to SMuFL’s own glyph ranges is accessible through this object. It is currently read-only, and retrieves it’s data from the ranges.json metadata file.

Parameters:

smufl (Smufl | None) – Parent Smufl.

While this object is normally created as part of a Font, an orphan Range object may be created like this:

>>> range = Range()
property description: str | None

Description of affiliated SMuFL range.

Example:

>>> range.description
Time signatures
property end: int | None

Returns end unicode of affiliated SMuFL range.

Example:

>>> range.end
U+E09F
property font: Font | None

Parent Font object.

property glyph: Glyph | None

Parent Glyph object.

property glyphs: Tuple[Glyph, ...] | None

Glyph objects of Affiliated SMuFL range.

Example:

>>> range.glyphs
(<Glyph 'uniE080' ('public.default') at 4596284000>,
...
<Glyph 'uniE09F' ('public.default') at 4632755792>)
property layer: Layer | None

Parent Layer object.

property name: str | None

Name of affiliated SMuFL range.

Example:

>>> range.name
timeSignatures
property smufl: Smufl | None

Parent Smufl object.

property start: int | None

Returns start unicode of affiliated SMuFL range.

Example:

>>> range.start
U+E080
